data.title: Cole Porter - Peru, IN - Grave of a Famous Person on Waymarking.com
data.meta_description: Waymarking.com is a way to mark unique locations on the planet and give them a voice. While GPS technology allows us to pinpoint any location on the planet, mark the location, and share it with others, Waymarking is the toolset for categorizing and adding unique information for that location.
data.text:
View waymark gallery

Cole Porter - Peru, IN

Posted by: hykesj

N 40° 45.609 W 086° 04.790

16T E 577667 N 4512539

Grave of Broadway composer and songwriter, Cole Porter.

Waymark Code: WM190MB

Location: Indiana, United States

Published By: Alfouine

Views: 0

Cole Porter was born in 1891 in the town of Peru, Indiana into the wealthiest family in town, possibly the wealthiest in the entire state. Not having to work for a living and finding he had a talent for songwriting, he was able to pursue his love of both music and the Broadway stage. After attending both Yale and Harvard (where he wrote some college fight songs that are still sung today) he tried his hand with a Broadway musical called ‘See America First.’

‘See America First’ was not very successful. In fact, much of Cole Porter’s output met with little success, but what was successful left us many memorable tunes: “Let's Do It (Let's Fall in Love),” “Anything Goes,” “I Get a Kick Out of You,” “Night and Day” and “You’re the Top.” He also had a few successful numbers written for the big screen such as “I've Got You under My Skin” and “In the Still of the Night.”

Porter lived a rather flamboyant lifestyle with homes in Paris and Venice. But a horseback riding accident in 1937 left him with a crushed leg which, in spite of 30 surgical procedures over the course of twenty years, still had to be amputated. Unable to walk and in constant pain, Cole Porter’s output declined but he was able to write the music for what could arguably be considered his best production: “Kiss Me, Kate.”

Cole Porter died in Santa Monica, California, in 1964 at the age of 73. He was buried in Mt. Hope Cemetery back in his hometown of Peru.

(Source: biography.com)

Visit Instructions:

To post a visit log for waymarks in this category, you must have personally visited the waymark location. When logging your visit, please provide a note describing your visit experience, along with any additional information about the waymark or the surrounding area that you think others may find interesting.

We especially encourage you to include any pictures that you took during your visit to the waymark. However, only respectful photographs are allowed. Logs which include photographs representing any form of disrespectful behavior (including those showing personal items placed on or near the grave location) will be subject to deletion.
